qas.question: What school has been recognized by the government?
What kind of state does Tajikistan see itself as?

answers.text: a secular state with a Constitution providing for freedom of religion

qas.question: What are the two national Islamic holidays?
What percent of the population is muslim?
What country has a Constitution providing for freedom of government?
Who has declared three Islamic holidays?
The population of which country is 88% Muslim?
Russian Christianity takes up what percent of the population?
Very few Muslims fast during what?

context: <a0_0>Sunni Islam of the Hanafi<a0_0/> school has been officially recognized by the government since 2009. <b4_0>Tajikistan<b4_0/> considers itself <a1_0>a secular state with a Constitution providing for freedom of religion<a1_0/>. <b5_0>The Government<b5_0/> has declared two Islamic holidays, <a2_0>Id Al-Fitr and Idi Qurbon<a2_0/>, as state holidays. According to a U.S. State Department release and Pew research group, the population of <b6_0>Tajikistan<b6_0/> is <a3_0>98%<a3_0/> Muslim. Approximately 87%–95% of them are Sunni and roughly 3% are Shia and roughly 7% are non-denominational Muslims. The remaining <b7_0>2%<b7_0/> of the population are followers of Russian Orthodoxy, Protestantism, Zoroastrianism and Buddhism. A great majority of Muslims fast during <b8_0>Ramadan<b8_0/>, although only about one third in the countryside and 10% in the cities observe daily prayer and dietary restrictions.
